title: RL31654
content: The Endangered Species Act (ESA) provides legal protection to identified species and their habitats, administered by the Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) and the National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS). Species can be listed as "endangered" or "threatened" based on extinction risk assessments. Legal tools under the ESA include prohibiting unpermitted "take" of endangered species and ensuring actions do not harm listed species or critical habitat. As of August 24, 2016, 2,266 species were listed as endangered or threatened. The Endangered Species Act (ESA) was passed in 1973 and has been amended multiple times since then. It aims to protect endangered and threatened species and their habitats. As of August 24, 2016, there were 2,266 listed species, with 1,593 in the United States. The ESA prohibits unpermitted "take" of species and ensures actions do not harm critical habitat. Funding for the ESA expired in 1992, but Congress has continued to appropriate funds.
